bibl.title: Letter from Florence M. Read to Laura Armistead Carter, September 17, 1925

div1.p: Read offers support to Laura Carter and invites her to stay with her in New York.

div1.head: Letter from Florence M. Read to Laura Armistead Carter, September 17, 1925
div1.p:
Please take this as
the grip of the hand I'd like
to give you this morning-
bearing both tribute and
affection. -- You are a
marvel in the way you
have been able to “carry on”
during these last months
and I suppose you'll keep
C1
B20
right on being one- It's in
the breed.

I want to repeat here
what I told you yesterday-
Just as soon as you feel like
it -- whenever it will be
a rest for you - or the least
relief to get away to new scenes
or the smallest satisfaction to
talk about the book which
was near your father's heart -
whenever the spirit moves on
any one of these counts. I
hope you will come to New
York & stay as long as you
feel like it. It happens that I have a
whole apartment at my disposition until the
12th or 15th of October - overlooking the
harbor - and I'd love to have you
come & stay with me. Those dates do
not mark the limit of the invitation!- Any
time, I'd love to have you come.

I know Dr. Russell is counting on your
further help on the book - but the pressure
of time is no longer an item - and the
very most important thing now is for you
to get as thorough and complete a rest
as possible. You will know better than
anyone else how you can best
accomplish that.
